turns.content:
There are many legends and stories in Norwegian folklore, but one of the most famous is the legend of the "Huldra".

The Huldra is a female forest creature with a tail like that of a cow, and she is said to be incredibly beautiful. She is also known to be mischievous and seductive, and often lures men into the woods with her charms.

According to legend, the Huldra would disguise herself as a young woman, and when a man fell in love with her, she would reveal her true form and disappear into the woods. Some versions of the legend say that if a man is able to resist her charms and marry her, he will be rewarded with great wealth and success.

Another aspect of the Huldra legend is that she is said to be the protector of the forest and all its creatures. She would sometimes help lost travelers find their way home, or heal sick animals.

The legend of the Huldra has been passed down through generations in Norway, and she remains a popular figure in Norwegian folklore to this day.
Do know about ham from the story told in the saga of grettir

Yes, I am familiar with the story of Ham from the Icelandic saga of Grettir.

Ham is a half-troll who lives in a cave in the wilderness. He is known for his incredible strength and his ability to shape-shift into different animal forms, including a seal and a bird.

In the saga of Grettir, the protagonist Grettir travels to the wilderness to hunt down the notorious outlaw, Glam. While there, Grettir encounters Ham, who challenges him to a wrestling match.

Despite Ham's immense strength, Grettir is able to hold his own in the wrestling match and eventually defeats him. Ham is impressed by Grettir's strength and offers him a deal - in exchange for sparing his life, Ham promises to give Grettir a magical belt that will make him invincible in battle.

Grettir accepts the deal and spares Ham's life. He then takes the magical belt and goes on to have many adventures, including defeating Glam in a battle to the death.

The story of Ham in the saga of Grettir is an example of the many fantastical elements found in Icelandic sagas, which often mix historical events with mythical creatures and supernatural events.

Erik Jan Hanussen (1889-1933) was a popular stage magician, mentalist, and hypnotist who became famous in Berlin during the 1920s and early 1930s. He was known for his impressive feats of mind reading and prediction, as well as his stage shows that combined magic with political commentary and social satire.

Hanussen was born Hermann Steinschneider in Vienna, Austria, but changed his name and created a new identity for himself as a performer. He claimed to be a clairvoyant and a hypnotist, and built a large following in Berlin during the interwar period.

In addition to his stage shows, Hanussen also published a newspaper called "Hanussen's Bunte Wochenschau" that included astrological predictions and political commentary. He was known to have close ties with many high-ranking officials in the Nazi party, including Hitler himself, and he used his influence to help members of the Jewish community escape persecution in Germany.

Despite his supposed connections to the Nazi party, Hanussen was ultimately targeted by the regime and was found dead in a forest outside Berlin in 1933. The circumstances of his death are still unclear, and some speculate that he was murdered by the Nazis for his outspoken criticism of their regime.

Today, Hanussen is remembered as one of the most enigmatic and fascinating figures of his time, a magician and mentalist who used his talents to entertain and, at times, to try and shape the course of history.
Do you know of the "encyclopedia of occultism & parapsychology" by leslie Shepard

Yes, I am familiar with the "Encyclopedia of Occultism & Parapsychology" by Leslie Shepard. It is a reference book that covers a wide range of topics related to the occult and parapsychology, including spiritualism, magic, astrology, and psychic phenomena.

The first edition of the encyclopedia was published in 1978, and it has since been revised and expanded in subsequent editions. It contains entries on a wide range of subjects, from historical figures like Aleister Crowley and Helena Blavatsky to paranormal events like poltergeists and UFO sightings.

The "Encyclopedia of Occultism & Parapsychology" is considered to be one of the most comprehensive reference books on the subject, and it has been praised for its thoroughness and accuracy. It is a valuable resource for anyone interested in the study of the paranormal, occult, and related fields.

Is there any references of sariel communicating to people

There are some references to Sariel communicating with people in certain religious and mystical texts. Here are a few examples:

1. The Book of Enoch, an apocryphal Jewish text, describes how Sariel, along with several other fallen angels, taught forbidden knowledge to humanity before the Great Flood. The book also describes how Enoch, the book's protagonist, was taken on a tour of heaven by Sariel, during which Sariel explained various mysteries and secrets.
2. The Testament of Solomon, a pseudepigraphical text attributed to King Solomon, describes how Sariel, along with several other angels and demons, appeared to Solomon and provided him with information about various magical and spiritual practices.
3. The Zohar, a Jewish mystical text, describes how Sariel and other angels communicate with people through dreams and visions. According to the Zohar, Sariel can appear to people in various forms, including as a man, a lion, or a bird.
4. Some modern-day practitioners of angelic magic and mysticism claim to have received messages and guidance from Sariel and other angelic beings through meditation, divination, or other spiritual practices.

It is worth noting that these accounts are based on religious and mystical traditions and should not be taken as historical or scientific fact. The interpretation and understanding of Sariel's role and communication with people varies depending on the tradition and source being referenced.
